multicol.title: Multicol
multicol.infoLine1: Left and right spacings are not rendered on mobile in order to make your content wider on smaller screens.
multicol.infoLine2: If you would like to use the same spacings on desktop and mobile views, please add a Box,
multicol.infoLine3: adjust its paddings/margins, and drop your multicolumn into that Box.

warningBox.line1: 600 px is still the safest email width these days.
warningBox.line2: Emails that are wider than 600-650 px might not fit into your subscribers' email reading pane in Outlook or Yahoo Mail on smaller screen sizes like 1366x768.

variableList.canNotEdit: You don't have permission to update this variable
variableList.canNotDelete: You don't have permission to delete this variable

variableList.findAndReplace: Find matching values and replace them with the variable

variablePreview.selectToPreview: Select a variable to see a more detailed preview of it.

rules.tooLong: The variable name is too long

color.line1: Thanks to the color variables, changing the color theme of your email becomes a breeze.
color.line2: As a best practice, we would advise you to define your most-used brand and text colors, at least.
color.line3: Once you have the color variables defined and associated with every desired element, you will be able to update their colors together.

fontStack.line1: Typography is an essential element in any brand identity, and it all starts with the font family.
fontStack.line2: As a best practice, we advise you to use a maximum of two different font families in your email: one for headings and one for paragraphs.
fontStack.line3: Once you have the font variables defined and associated with every desired element, you will be able to update them together.

image.line1: The image variables can help you replace brand-specific image elements in your email template conveniently.
image.line2: As a best practice, we advise you to define the company logo, custom icons, image backgrounds, or other repetitive decorator elements as image variables.
image.line3: Once you have the image variables defined and associated with every desired element, you will be able to update them together.

link.line1: The link variables can help you replace brand-specific links in your email template conveniently.
link.line2: Any link that's not being added via a merge tag but is necessary multiple times in an email, for example, a link to your homepage, should be defined as a link variable instead of a regular URL.
link.line3: This way, if you wish to reuse the email with a different brand or need to update it, you'll be able to replace those links in it together.

text.line1: Text variables were born to let you customize the written content of multiple text values just like, buttons, ALT texts, or titles together.
text.line2: For example, instead of writing "Read more" on every button in your email template, you could create a "button-text-1" variable and assign it to each of them.
text.line3: Later, if you need to replace the call-to-action on the buttons, you will only need to modify the value of your text variable once.

addTextVariable.label: Text
addTextVariable.modeSwitchLabelInfo: Save variable without HTML tags and use them as Alt-text or Link title

errors.supportedFileTypes: Supported file types: jpg, jpeg, png and gif only!
